Hi everyone,
I have a very basic question, but one that has been bothering me for a while.
Julia being column major order I would expect this:
```function r_col_loop(x::Array{T}) where T
    N = size(x,2)
    r = Array{T,1}(undef,N)

    @inbounds for i = 1:N
        x2 = 0.0
        for dim = 1:3
            x2 += x[dim, i]^2
        end
        r[i] = √( x2 )
    end
    return r
end```
to be faster than this:
```function r_row_loop(x::Array{T}) where T
    N = size(x,1)
    r = Array{T,1}(undef,N)

    @inbounds for i = 1:N
        x2 = 0.0
        for dim = 1:3
            x2 += x[i, dim]^2
        end
        r[i] = √( x2 )
    end
    return r
end```
but when I time it I get:
```x_row = rand(1_000_000, 3)
@btime r_row_loop($x_row)
    1.770 ms (2 allocations: 7.63 MiB)

x_col = rand(3, 1_000_000)
@btime r_col_loop($x_col)
    1.965 ms (2 allocations: 7.63 MiB)```
The difference is even larger when I use broadcasting with `@views`:
```function r_row_dot(x::Array{T}) where T
    @views @. √( x[:,1]^2 + x[:,2]^2 + x[:,3]^2)
end
@btime r_row_dot($x_row)
    1.536 ms (2 allocations: 7.63 MiB)

function r_col_dot(x::Array{T}) where T
    @views @. √( x[1,:]^2 + x[2,:]^2 + x[3,:]^2)
end
@btime r_col_dot($x_col)
    1.933 ms (2 allocations: 7.63 MiB)```
I'm obviously missing/misunderstanding a crucial part here, could someone please help me out?
